Diăn Jié 顛頡 of Jin accompanied Duke Wen of Jin during 19 years of exile [ZUO Xi 23]. He was appointed a dignitary 大夫 upon the accession of Duke Wen to the throne. When prevented by Duke Wen from entering a palace full of possible war booty, he set fire to that palace in anger and was killed for this by his Duke and benefactor. [ZUO Xi 28] HF 34.29 and 34.44. Unger no. 742
Unger no. 868

Dŏng Èyú 董閼于 (d. 496) from Jin, also known as Dong Anyu 董安于 or Dongzi 董子, served under prime minister >Zhào Jiănzĭ 趙簡子 (fl. 517-475) whom he warned against a serious plot by by the Fan 范 and Zhonghang 中行 clans in Jin against the powerful influence of the Zhao 趙 clan. (ZUO Ding 14, ed Wang Shouqian p. 496 gives a lively narrative of the ensuing intrigues against Dong at the end of which Dong declares that his own death would contribute to a solution of the situation, and he kills himself.). Dong remained a much quoted example of utterly selfless loyalty of a minister to his lord. [See HF 30.18, etc.] Unger no. 773
Standard Name: Li Fú Xū 里鳧須 (Floruit ca. 636-628)Unger no. 447
Unger no. 909
Unger no. 845

Fàn Wénzĭ 范文子 (d. 574), also known as Shì Xiè 士燮, was the son of Shi Hui 士會, a dignitary in the state of Jin 晉. ZUO Cheng 2 praises him for insisting on a late return from a victorious battle against the state of Qi in 589 on the grounds that if he had returned early the honour for the victory would all have been his and not the army’s. His typical role in the old sources is throughout that of a wise adviser. In 575 he is said to have advised against an a military campaign by Jin against the state of Zheng 鄭. [SY 5.17] [ZUO Cheng 2 to Cheng 16 passim; SJ 39] [Fang Zhaohui 2002: 311-318]

Gōng Zhīqí 宮之奇 (fl. 658). A courtier in the small state of Yú 虞, whose advice to appease the much larger state of Jin 晉 and allow them right of way through Yu territory went unheeded in a famous episode. The result was the destruction of the state of Yú 虞 at the hands of neighbouring much larger state of Jin 晉.This famous episode occurred in 658 and is reported in lively detail in ZUO Xi 5. [MENG 5A9; GULIANG Xi 4; XUN 32; LSCQ 15.4, 22.5, ZGC passim]

Bì Xī 佛肸 was a domestic officer of the Fàn 范 clan in Jìn, who had been put in charge of the town of Zhōngmóu 中牟 (loc. near Xīngtái and Hándān, Héběi Provence), in Spring and Autumn times. This Zhōngmóu was in Jìn territory.
